keyTakeAways: Electricity bills are rising across the U.S. due to increased demand from AI-powered computing, especially in data centers.
The average price of electricity has increased 13% since 2022, with regional spikes in the Pacific, Middle Atlantic, and New England.
AI development is driving a surge in power consumption, with tech giants like Meta and Microsoft investing billions in data centers.
Data centers are projected to consume 6.7% to 12% of U.S. electricity by 2028, up from 4.4% in 2023.
A partnership between OpenAI and Broadcom to build 10 gigawatts of custom AI chips—enough to power a major city—exemplifies the scale of AI-related energy demand.
Electricity pricing models have not been updated to reflect data center demand, leading to higher costs for residential consumers.
Some states like Oregon have passed legislation requiring data centers to pay for grid strain, preventing cost shifts to homeowners.
AI tools are becoming more computationally intensive, requiring significant energy for complex tasks like video generation and website coding.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Electricity bills across the U.S. are rising due to a surge in demand from AI-driven data centers. This demand is fueled by massive investments from tech companies like Meta and Microsoft, and partnerships such as OpenAI and Broadcom's plan to build 10 gigawatts of custom AI chips. The Department of Energy projects data centers will consume 6.7% to 12% of U.S. electricity by 2028, up from 4.4% in 2023. Experts note that electricity pricing models have not adapted to this rise in demand, leading to higher costs for residential consumers. While some states like Oregon have introduced legislation to require data centers to pay for grid strain, the broader trend reflects a significant shift in energy consumption patterns tied to artificial intelligence growth.
title: Is AI really making electricity bills higher? Here’s what the experts say
